title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO and the invitation is accepted by the Ukrainian government. The invitation must be documented in an official NATO communiquÃ© or similar authoritative source. Additionally, the acceptance must be confirmed by a public statement from the President of Ukraine or the Ukrainian government. The resolution will also consider the status of Ukraine's membership in NATO if it has completed all necessary reforms and met the criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's Membership Action Plan. Any temporary or conditional invitations that do not lead to full membership by the specified date do not count towards a Yes resolution.

title: Will Ukraine achieve a membership action plan with NATO by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Ukraine is officially granted a Membership Action Plan (MAP) by NATO. The decision must be confirmed through an official NATO announcement or documentation. The criteria for a MAP include Ukraine's demonstrated commitment to the principles of democracy, individual liberty, and the rule of law, as well as its ability to contribute to NATO's collective defense. Any interim agreements or discussions will not count towards this resolution unless they culminate in an official MAP grant. The resolution will also account for any significant political changes or events that may affect NATO's decision-making process regarding Ukraine's membership aspirations.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will NATO increase military support to Ukraine before 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if NATO officially announces an increase in military support to Ukraine before January 1, 2028. An increase in military support is defined as any of the following: a significant increase in the number of troops deployed, an increase in the volume of military equipment or supplies sent, or the provision of new types of military aid that were not previously provided. The announcement must be confirmed by credible sources, including at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary increases for specific events or training exercises do not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will Ukraine resolve its territorial disputes with Russia before joining NATO?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if Ukraine officially resolves its territorial disputes with Russia before December 31, 2023, through a formal agreement recognized by both parties and supported by at least one major international body (e.g., the United Nations, NATO). The resolution must involve clear terms regarding the disputed territories, and any agreements must be publicly announced and documented. In the absence of such an agreement, the question will resolve as No. Temporary ceasefires or informal negotiations do not count as a resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will Ukraine hold a referendum on NATO membership before 2027?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2027, Ukraine holds an official referendum regarding its membership in NATO. The referendum must be recognized by the Ukrainian government and conducted according to international electoral standards. The results must be reported by credible news sources, including at least two of the following: BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, or Washington Post. Any unofficial polls or surveys will not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will NATO expand its presence in Eastern Europe before Ukraine joins?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if NATO officially announces an expansion of its military presence in Eastern Europe before Ukraine is granted full NATO membership. The announcement must be made through a credible source such as an official NATO press release or a statement from a high-ranking NATO official. The expansion must involve the deployment of additional troops, military bases, or significant military resources in Eastern European member states. The question will resolve as No if Ukraine joins NATO before any such announcement is made, regardless of any discussions or plans that may have been proposed prior to that date.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled to take place in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by recognized authorities such as the United Nations, the European Union, or the United States. The term 'international sanctions' refers to restrictions imposed on a country by the international community, which may include trade restrictions, financial embargoes, and travel bans. The hosting of the Grand Prix must be confirmed by an official announcement from Formula 1 or the relevant governing body. If the event is canceled or relocated for any reason, this question will resolve as No. Temporary or unofficial races do not count towards this resolution.

title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially held in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by a recognized authority such as the United Nations or the European Union. The term 'international sanctions' refers to restrictions imposed on a country that may include trade embargoes, financial restrictions, or other punitive measures aimed at influencing the country's policies. The event must be part of the official Formula 1 calendar and must take place as a full race, not a demonstration or exhibition. In case of multiple races, the first instance of such a race will determine the resolution. If the country is removed from sanctions after the race is announced but before the race occurs, it will still count towards a Yes resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will any international sporting event be held in a country under sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, any international sporting event (as defined by the International Olympic Committee or FIFA) is held in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by the United Nations or the European Union. The event must be officially recognized and sanctioned by the relevant international sporting federation. For the purposes of this question, 'sanctions' refer to any economic, trade, or diplomatic restrictions imposed on a country. Temporary or unofficial events do not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will Formula 1 expand to new countries that are currently not on the calendar by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Formula 1 has officially included new countries in its racing calendar that were not part of the calendar prior to 2023. The inclusion of a new country must be confirmed by an official announcement from Formula 1 or its governing body, the FIA. The new races must take place in the specified countries and be part of the official championship. Temporary or one-off races do not count unless they are part of a multi-year agreement to host Formula 1 races in that country. Additionally, the new countries must be recognized sovereign states.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will there be a significant change in international sanctions policy affecting sports by 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, there is a significant change in international sanctions policy that directly affects sports. A significant change is defined as: 
- The introduction of new international sanctions that explicitly target sports organizations or athletes, or 
- The lifting of existing sanctions that have previously restricted the participation of athletes or teams in international competitions. 
The change must be recognized and reported by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must have a clear and documented impact on the ability of athletes or teams to compete internationally. Temporary measures or actions that do not result in a formal policy change will not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will a Formula 1 team be sponsored by a company from a sanctioned country by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 team officially announces a sponsorship deal with a company based in a country currently under international sanctions as defined by the United Nations or the European Union. The sponsorship must involve financial support or branding on the team's cars or uniforms. The resolution will be based on official announcements from the Formula 1 team or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). Any sponsorship arrangement that is temporary, limited to specific events, or involves a company that is not directly sanctioned will not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Senate has passed legislation that significantly alters or establishes new nuclear safety standards. Significant legislation is defined as any bill that: 
- Introduces new safety regulations for nuclear power plants, including but not limited to operational, environmental, or safety protocols. 
- Amends existing laws such as the Atomic Energy Act or the Nuclear Waste Policy Act in a way that enhances safety standards. 
The legislation must be officially signed into law by the President of the United States. The resolution will rely on official congressional records and reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) for verification. If multiple bills are introduced, at least one must be passed and signed into law for the resolution to be Yes.

title: Will the US House of Representatives pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US House of Representatives has passed legislation that significantly alters nuclear safety standards. Significant alterations are defined as any changes that enhance safety protocols, increase regulatory oversight, or modify existing safety requirements for nuclear facilities. The legislation must be officially documented in the Congressional Record and must be signed into law by the President. If the legislation is passed but subsequently vetoed, the question will resolve as No. Additionally, any legislation that is purely administrative or procedural in nature, without substantive changes to safety standards, will not count towards a Yes resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will any state-level legislation regarding nuclear safety standards be enacted before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, any U.S. state enacts legislation that establishes or amends nuclear safety standards. The legislation must be officially documented and publicly available. The criteria for 'nuclear safety standards' include regulations related to the construction, operation, and decommissioning of nuclear facilities, as well as safety protocols for the handling of nuclear materials. Legislation that is merely proposed or under consideration will not count. The resolution will reference the official state legislative records or reputable news sources that report on the enactment of such legislation.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will there be a major public safety incident related to nuclear facilities in the US before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, any of the following occurs: (1) a significant nuclear incident classified as a Level 3 or higher on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES) occurs at a nuclear facility in the US, resulting in public exposure to radiation or a public safety alert; (2) a major security breach at a nuclear facility that leads to a credible threat to public safety, as reported by a reputable news source (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post); (3) an event causing a substantial evacuation or emergency response related to a nuclear facility, officially recognized by government agencies such as the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). Minor incidents or routine safety drills do not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will international nuclear safety standards influence US legislation by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Congress passes legislation that incorporates international nuclear safety standards into its regulatory framework. The legislation must explicitly reference adherence to standards set by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) or similar authoritative bodies. The influence of international standards must be clearly stated in the legislative text. This question resolves as No if no such legislation is passed by the specified date, regardless of discussions or proposals regarding nuclear safety standards.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will the US government increase funding for nuclear safety research by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US government has officially increased funding for nuclear safety research compared to the funding levels of 2024. The increase must be documented in an official budget proposal or appropriations bill passed by Congress. The increase must be at least 10% above the 2024 funding level for nuclear safety research as defined by the Department of Energy and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Any funding increases that are temporary, one-time allocations, or related to specific projects without ongoing commitment do not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the European Union has officially implemented a unified nuclear waste management policy that is recognized and adopted by all member states. The policy must include standardized procedures for the handling, storage, and disposal of nuclear waste across the EU, and it must be formally adopted through a legislative process involving the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union. The implementation must be confirmed by an official EU announcement or documentation. In the absence of such an announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient to confirm the policy's adoption. Temporary measures or pilot programs do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the European Union increase funding for nuclear waste research by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the European Union officially announces an increase in funding for nuclear waste research compared to the funding levels of 2023. The increase must be documented in an official EU budget or funding proposal. The announcement must be covered by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). Any temporary or one-time funding boosts that do not constitute a permanent increase will not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will any EU member state adopt a national nuclear waste management policy before 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, any EU member state has officially adopted a national nuclear waste management policy that includes specific provisions for the safe storage, transport, and disposal of nuclear waste. The policy must be publicly available and recognized by the respective government, and it should be compliant with EU regulations and guidelines regarding nuclear waste management. The resolution will be based on official government announcements or legislation, and credible reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the adoption of such a policy. Temporary measures or pilot programs do not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will the European Union achieve a consensus on nuclear energy regulations by 2032?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, the European Union has reached a formal consensus on nuclear energy regulations, which must include agreements on safety standards, waste management, and investment in nuclear technology. The consensus must be documented in an official EU legislative act or a joint declaration by the member states. The resolution will also consider any major news reports from reputable sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the consensus. In the event of partial agreements or differing regulations among member states, the question will resolve as No unless a unified framework is established that applies to all member states.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will the European Union establish a centralized nuclear waste storage facility by 2035?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, the European Union has officially established a centralized nuclear waste storage facility that is operational and accepting nuclear waste from member states. The facility must be recognized and regulated by the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) and comply with all relevant EU safety and environmental regulations. Confirmation of the establishment must come from an official EU announcement or reputable news sources (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). If the facility is partially operational or limited to specific member states, it must be intended for full EU-wide operation to resolve as Yes. Temporary or trial facilities do not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will public opinion in EU countries support nuclear energy as a solution to climate change by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a majority of public opinion polls conducted in EU countries indicate that at least 50% of respondents support the use of nuclear energy as a solution to climate change. The polls must be conducted by reputable polling organizations and published in recognized media outlets. The question of support for nuclear energy must be clearly defined in the polls as relating to its role in addressing climate change, specifically. If there is a significant variance in support across different countries, the resolution will still be based on the overall majority across the EU. Additionally, support must be consistent over at least three separate polls conducted within the last year leading up to the resolution date.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is clear evidence of a significant increase in global soccer viewership attributed to the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. Specifically, this will be measured by: 1. An increase of at least 20% in the average global viewership numbers for the World Cup compared to the previous tournament with 32 teams in 2018. 2. Official reports from FIFA or credible third-party sources (such as Nielsen or similar audience measurement organizations) confirming this increase. 3. The increase must be directly linked to the expanded format, meaning that viewership figures must show a correlation with the expansion and not be influenced by other factors (e.g., the popularity of specific teams or players). In the absence of clear data from FIFA, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, etc.) will suffice to confirm the increase.

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a higher number of participating countries in future tournaments by 2034?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2034, at least 5 additional countries that have never previously qualified for the FIFA World Cup qualify for the tournament following the expansion to 48 teams. The qualification must be confirmed by FIFA and publicly reported by reputable news sources such as BBC, The Guardian, or the New York Times. If the expansion leads to a tournament where fewer than 48 teams participate, this question will resolve as No. Additionally, if the expansion results in a decrease in the overall number of unique countries participating compared to the last tournament before the expansion, the resolution will also be No.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams result in an increase in sponsorship revenue for FIFA by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, FIFA reports an increase in sponsorship revenue directly attributable to the expansion of the FIFA World Cup to 48 teams, compared to the sponsorship revenue from the last World Cup held with 32 teams in 2018. The increase must be at least 10% in real terms, adjusted for inflation. The revenue figures must be publicly disclosed in FIFA's financial statements or through reputable news sources such as BBC, The Guardian, or the New York Times. If FIFA does not provide a clear report, credible reports from at least three major news organizations confirming the increase will suffice. Any sponsorship revenue from unrelated events or tournaments will not be considered.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to the introduction of new soccer markets by 2032?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, at least two new soccer markets are officially recognized and established as part of the FIFA World Cup framework resulting from the expansion to 48 teams. A 'new soccer market' is defined as a country or region that has never qualified for the FIFA World Cup prior to 2026 and has a national team that competes in the tournament. The recognition must be confirmed by FIFA and reported by reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, etc.). If there are any disputes about the recognition of new markets, the decision will be based on FIFA's official rankings and announcements.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams cause a significant increase in youth soccer participation globally by 2035?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, there is credible evidence showing a significant increase in youth soccer participation globally attributed to the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. A significant increase is defined as at least a 20% rise in registered youth soccer players in at least 10 countries compared to the baseline year of 2022. The evidence must be supported by data from reputable sources such as FIFA, national soccer federations, or recognized sports research organizations. Reports must be published in credible sports news outlets or academic journals. Participation increases must be directly linked to the World Cup expansion, excluding other factors such as local leagues' initiatives or unrelated events.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the leader in global digital governance based on the following criteria: 
- South Korea must have implemented comprehensive digital governance policies that are adopted and followed by at least 75% of its population, as verified by government reports and independent surveys. 
- South Korea must hold a prominent position in international digital governance forums, such as the OECD and G20, where it leads discussions and initiatives on digital policy, cybersecurity, and data privacy. 
- The country must be acknowledged in at least three reputable international reports or rankings (e.g., by the World Economic Forum, UN, or similar organizations) as the top nation in digital governance practices. 
- Significant collaborations or partnerships with at least three other countries in establishing global digital standards must be in place, with documented agreements and initiatives. 
In the absence of clear consensus, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will South Korea establish a comprehensive digital identity system by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, South Korea has officially established a comprehensive digital identity system that is accessible to all citizens. The system must include features such as secure authentication, verification of identity for online services, and integration with government services. The establishment of this system must be confirmed through an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of such an announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (such as BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will suffice. The system must be fully operational and not in a pilot or trial phase. If the system is partially implemented (e.g., limited to specific services or demographics), it will only count if there is a clear intention and timeline for nationwide implementation.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

title: Will South Korea lead the development of international digital privacy standards by 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, South Korea has established itself as the leading nation in the development of international digital privacy standards. This will be determined by at least one of the following criteria being met: 1) South Korea has hosted an international conference where a comprehensive digital privacy framework is proposed and adopted by at least five other countries; 2) South Korea's proposed digital privacy standards are officially endorsed by a recognized international organization such as the United Nations or the OECD; 3) South Korea has implemented these standards domestically and received international recognition for its efforts in digital privacy from a reputable source such as the BBC, The Guardian, or the New York Times. The resolution will also consider the influence of South Korea's standards on global practices, as evidenced by adoption or adaptation by other nations.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

title: Will South Korea's digital governance model be adopted by at least three other countries by 2032?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, at least three countries have officially adopted a digital governance model that closely resembles South Korea's model, which includes the integration of digital services, citizen engagement platforms, and data-driven decision-making processes. The adoption must be confirmed by official government announcements or documented policies that outline the implementation of such a model. The countries must be recognized sovereign states and the adoption must be operational, not merely in a proposal or planning stage. If a country adopts a modified version of the model, it will still count towards the resolution as long as it retains the core principles of South Korea's digital governance.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

title: Will South Korea implement nationwide 5G infrastructure by 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, South Korea has fully implemented nationwide 5G infrastructure that provides high-speed internet access to at least 95% of the population. The implementation must be confirmed by the South Korean government or a reputable telecommunications authority. The infrastructure must be operational and capable of delivering speeds of at least 1 Gbps under normal conditions. Reports from at least three major news organizations (such as the Korea Herald, Yonhap News, or international outlets like BBC or Reuters) confirming the implementation will also suffice. Partial implementations in specific areas or temporary setups for events do not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

title: Will South Korea host a major international summit on digital governance by 2026?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, South Korea has officially hosted a major international summit focused on digital governance. The summit must include participation from at least 10 countries and involve discussions on key topics such as data privacy, cybersecurity, and international regulations on digital platforms. The event must be confirmed by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times) and must not be a smaller regional meeting or a virtual conference. In the case of multiple summits, only the first one that meets these criteria will be considered for resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, credible evidence demonstrates that Microsoft's carbon negative pledge has led to a measurable reduction in global CO2 levels. The reduction must be at least 1% of global CO2 emissions compared to levels recorded in 2020, as reported by authoritative sources such as the Global Carbon Project or the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The impact must be attributed directly to Microsoft's initiatives and not to other external factors or global events. The evidence must be supported by peer-reviewed research or official reports from reputable organizations (e.g., UN, World Resources Institute) that analyze the effectiveness of corporate carbon pledges on global emissions.

title: Will other major tech companies follow Microsoft's lead in committing to carbon negative pledges by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, at least three major technology companies (defined as companies with a market capitalization over $10 billion) publicly commit to carbon negative pledges. A carbon negative pledge must include a clear plan to remove more carbon dioxide from the atmosphere than the company emits, with specific targets and timelines outlined. The commitment must be reported in a reputable news source (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or through an official press release from the company. Companies that have previously made similar commitments without updates or new pledges do not count toward this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?

title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative initiatives lead to a measurable decrease in CO2 emissions in the tech sector by 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, there is a measurable and independently verified decrease in CO2 emissions attributable to Microsoft's carbon negative initiatives within the tech sector. The decrease must be quantified and reported by a reputable third-party organization, such as the Carbon Trust or similar, and must represent a statistically significant reduction compared to baseline emissions data from 2020. The tech sector is defined as companies primarily engaged in the development and distribution of technology products and services, including software, hardware, and internet services. Any claims must be substantiated by credible reports from at least two major news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post).

metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?

title: Will global CO2 levels reach a peak before 2030 despite Microsoft's carbon negative pledge?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, global CO2 levels reach a peak and subsequently decline, as reported by authoritative sources such as the Global Carbon Project or the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). A peak is defined as a maximum recorded level of atmospheric CO2, followed by a decrease in levels over at least a consecutive 12-month period. The CO2 levels must be measured and reported in parts per million (ppm) and confirmed by multiple reputable scientific organizations. Microsoft's carbon negative pledge will not affect the resolution of this question, as it pertains to global CO2 levels, not just those influenced by Microsoft. Edge cases include temporary fluctuations due to natural events, which will not count as a peak if they do not lead to a sustained decline.

metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?

title: Will governmental policies be enacted to support corporate carbon negative efforts by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, any government (federal, state, or local) enacts policies specifically designed to support corporate efforts to achieve carbon negativity. These policies must include measurable incentives such as tax breaks, grants, or subsidies aimed at reducing carbon emissions beyond neutrality. The policies must be publicly documented and verifiable through official government publications or announcements. Additionally, credible reports from at least two major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the enactment of such policies will also suffice. Policies that are merely proposals or in draft form will not count towards resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?

title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge inspire similar commitments in the manufacturing industry by 2032?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, at least three major manufacturing companies publicly announce and commit to carbon negative pledges that are inspired by Microsoft's carbon negative initiative. The pledges must include specific targets for carbon reduction and timelines that are clearly defined. The announcements must be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must be verifiable through official corporate communications or sustainability reports. A commitment must include measurable actions and not just intentions or vague statements. If a company retracts its commitment or fails to implement its pledge within the specified timeline, it will not count towards the resolution of this question.

metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?

title: Will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2040, a scientifically validated breakthrough in physics is announced that leads to a new form of clean energy. The criteria for a 'breakthrough' includes: 1. The discovery or theoretical development must be published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal. 2. The new energy form must be capable of being harnessed for practical use, demonstrated through experimental evidence or prototypes. 3. The clean energy must significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions compared to current energy sources and be scalable for widespread use. 4. The breakthrough must be recognized by a consensus of leading physicists and energy experts, as indicated by endorsements from reputable scientific organizations or institutions. If the breakthrough is announced but not yet operational or scalable, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will a major breakthrough in energy storage technology occur by 2035?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, a significant breakthrough in energy storage technology is achieved and recognized by the scientific community. A 'major breakthrough' is defined as: 
1. A new energy storage technology that demonstrates at least a 50% improvement in energy density compared to current leading technologies (e.g., lithium-ion batteries), or 
2. A novel technology that enables energy storage at a cost of less than $100 per kWh at scale, or 
3. A technology that allows for energy storage duration exceeding 10 hours with minimal degradation over time.

This breakthrough must be validated by independent research and published in a peer-reviewed journal or recognized by major energy conferences, and it should be covered by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). The resolution will also consider the consensus of experts in the field of energy storage.

metadata.source_question: Will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040?

title: Will fusion energy become commercially viable before 2050?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2050, there is a commercially viable fusion energy system that meets the following criteria: The system must produce more energy than it consumes (net positive energy output), and it must be capable of operating continuously for at least 1 year. Additionally, the system must be available for commercial use, meaning it can be purchased or leased by private entities for energy production. Verification of this must come from credible sources, including government agencies, reputable scientific organizations, or major news outlets such as BBC, The Guardian, or New York Times. In the event that multiple systems claim commercial viability, the resolution will be based on the first system that meets these criteria, with confirmation from the aforementioned sources.

metadata.source_question: Will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040?

title: Will a new clean energy technology be adopted by a major country by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major country (defined as a member of the G20) officially adopts a new clean energy technology that significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions compared to existing technologies. The technology must be recognized by a reputable international body, such as the International Energy Agency (IEA) or the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Adoption is defined as the technology being implemented in a national policy or program, with measurable targets for deployment. Technologies that are in trial phases or limited to pilot projects do not count towards this resolution. Additionally, the technology must have been developed or significantly improved in the last 10 years to qualify as 'new'.

metadata.source_question: Will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040?

title: Will there be a significant reduction in global carbon emissions by 2045 due to new energy technologies?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2045, there is a significant reduction in global carbon emissions (defined as at least a 30% decrease from 2020 levels) that can be attributed to the deployment of new energy technologies. These technologies must include renewable energy sources (such as solar, wind, and hydroelectric power) and must be implemented at a scale that is verifiable by authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA) or the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The reduction must be documented in credible reports from these organizations or major news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). In the case of partial reductions, the question will resolve as Yes if the trend indicates a clear path towards the defined target by the specified date.

metadata.source_question: Will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040?

title: Will public investment in renewable energy research double by 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, the total public investment in renewable energy research in any country or region is at least double the amount invested in the year 2023. The investment must be publicly reported in credible sources, such as government budgets or official reports from recognized energy agencies. The definition of 'renewable energy research' includes research and development in solar, wind, hydro, geothermal, and biomass energy technologies. Investments in fossil fuel research or non-renewable energy sources do not count towards this question's resolution. If there is any ambiguity in reported figures, resolution will depend on the consensus of at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, etc.) confirming the investment figures.

metadata.source_question: Will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040?

title: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares a global health emergency specifically related to diseases that are directly attributable to climate change. The declaration must be made in a formal statement or report from the WHO and must identify specific diseases that are exacerbated by climate change, such as vector-borne diseases (e.g., malaria, dengue), respiratory diseases (e.g., asthma, allergies), and waterborne diseases (e.g., cholera). The declaration should be based on scientific evidence and consensus from the global health community, including input from epidemiologists and climate scientists. The resolution will not count declarations that are vague or general in nature without specific reference to climate-related diseases.

title: Will a new climate-related disease emerge that significantly impacts global health by 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, a new disease is identified and classified as climate-related by the World Health Organization (WHO) or another reputable international health authority. The disease must meet the following criteria: (1) It must be directly linked to climate change, such as through increased vector-borne transmission due to rising temperatures, or through environmental changes that facilitate the emergence of pathogens. (2) It must have a significant impact on global health, defined as causing at least 100,000 reported cases or leading to substantial mortality rates across multiple countries. (3) The identification and classification must be supported by peer-reviewed research and widely reported by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). In the absence of such classification, credible reports from at least three major health organizations or institutions will suffice to resolve the question as Yes.

metadata.source_question: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?

title: Will the WHO implement new guidelines for climate-related health risks by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the World Health Organization (WHO) has officially published and implemented new guidelines specifically addressing climate-related health risks. These guidelines must be publicly available on the WHO's official website and must include actionable recommendations for member states to mitigate health risks associated with climate change. The guidelines should be recognized and endorsed by the WHO's governing bodies. In the absence of such a publication, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the implementation of these guidelines will suffice. Temporary recommendations or frameworks that are not formalized as guidelines do not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?

title: Will there be a significant increase in funding for climate-related health research by 2032?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, there is a documented increase in funding for climate-related health research by at least 25% compared to the funding levels reported in 2021. This increase must be confirmed by reputable sources such as government reports, major health organizations (e.g., WHO, CDC), or peer-reviewed publications. The funding increase must be specifically allocated to research that directly addresses the health impacts of climate change, including but not limited to studies on heat-related illnesses, vector-borne diseases, and mental health impacts due to climate stressors. In the absence of government reports, confirmation from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times) is required. Temporary funding boosts for specific projects do not count unless they contribute to the overall increase in the designated area.

metadata.source_question: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?

title: Will a major country experience a climate-related health crisis that prompts international intervention by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major country experiences a climate-related health crisis that meets the following criteria and prompts international intervention: 

1. The health crisis must be directly linked to climate change, such as extreme heat events, widespread disease outbreaks exacerbated by climate conditions, or significant food and water shortages due to climate impacts. 
2. The crisis must result in a declaration of a national emergency or similar governmental response indicating the severity of the situation. 
3. International intervention must be initiated, which can include humanitarian aid, medical assistance, or military support from other countries or international organizations (e.g., WHO, UN). 

The resolution will be based on credible reports from at least two major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the crisis and the international response. In cases where the situation is ambiguous or contested, the resolution will be based on the consensus of health and climate experts as reported in reputable scientific publications.

metadata.source_question: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?

title: Will public awareness of climate-related health issues significantly increase by 2027?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, there is clear evidence of a significant increase in public awareness of climate-related health issues. This can be demonstrated by: 
1. A minimum of three major national or international surveys conducted by reputable organizations (e.g., Pew Research Center, Gallup) indicating that at least 60% of respondents acknowledge a direct connection between climate change and health issues. 
2. At least five major news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) publish articles or reports specifically addressing climate-related health issues, including statistics or expert opinions, during the year 2027. 
3. Increased engagement on social media platforms (e.g., a 50% increase in posts, shares, or discussions about climate-related health issues compared to 2026). 
4. Official reports or statements from health organizations (e.g., WHO, CDC) highlighting the impact of climate change on public health in 2027. 
The resolution will be based on the consensus of the above criteria.

metadata.source_question: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?

title: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, India is recognized as a global leader in quantum computing based on the following criteria: 1. India must have established a significant number of operational quantum computing facilities that are recognized internationally, with at least 5 facilities being operational and producing quantum computing solutions. 2. India must have made substantial contributions to quantum computing research, with at least 50 peer-reviewed publications in top-tier journals and conferences acknowledged by the quantum computing community. 3. India must have developed and deployed quantum computing applications that are utilized by industry and government, demonstrating practical use cases. 4. Recognition by authoritative sources such as the International Quantum Computing Association or similar organizations, stating India's leadership position in the global quantum computing landscape. If these criteria are not met by the specified date, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will India establish a national quantum computing research institute by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Government of India officially announces the establishment of a national quantum computing research institute. The institute must be designed to conduct research and development in quantum computing technologies and must have a defined budget and operational framework. The announcement must be made through official government channels or reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Times of India). If the institute is established but not operational by this date, the question will resolve as No.

metadata.source_question: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?

title: Will India produce a functional quantum computer that surpasses 100 qubits by 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, India has produced a functional quantum computer that is capable of operating with more than 100 qubits. The quantum computer must be publicly demonstrated to perform a quantum algorithm that showcases its capabilities, such as quantum supremacy or a significant computational advantage over classical computers. The demonstration must be reported by at least two reputable sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must be verified by independent experts in the field of quantum computing. The definition of 'functional' means that the quantum computer can reliably manipulate and measure qubits without significant errors that would undermine its performance.

metadata.source_question: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?

title: Will India collaborate with another country on a major quantum computing project by 2027?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, India has officially entered into a collaborative agreement with another country on a major quantum computing project. A 'major quantum computing project' is defined as a project with a budget exceeding $50 million and involving significant research and development efforts in quantum technologies. The collaboration must be publicly announced by the governments or relevant agencies of both India and the collaborating country. Credible reports from at least three major news organizations (such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, etc.) confirming the collaboration will also suffice for resolution. If the project is canceled or significantly downsized, the question will resolve as No.

metadata.source_question: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?

title: Will Indian universities be ranked among the top 10 in quantum computing research by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, at least one Indian university is ranked among the top 10 universities globally in quantum computing research according to the QS World University Rankings or the Times Higher Education World University Rankings. The rankings must be based on recognized metrics of research output, impact, and academic reputation in the field of quantum computing. The ranking must be officially published by either QS or Times Higher Education. In the event that multiple rankings are published, the resolution will be based on the most authoritative and widely recognized ranking available at that time.

metadata.source_question: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?

title: Will India implement a national policy to promote quantum technology development by 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, the Government of India has officially implemented a national policy that includes specific measures to promote the development of quantum technology. The policy must outline funding allocations, research initiatives, and partnerships with academic and industry stakeholders. The implementation must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Any interim measures or proposals will not count towards this resolution; only a formally adopted policy will suffice.
